messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 21, 2021 - July 27, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-28T20:47:25Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-07-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-07-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210728-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 5 C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at the NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the combined front of two C-type CMEs (first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-07-23T21:36Z and 2021-07-24T00:36Z) would impact Solar Orbiter at 2021-07-26T20:40Z, STEREO A at 2021-07-27T02:20Z, and give a glancing blow at NASA missions Earth at 2021-07-27T08:00Z (+- 7 hours) (see notification 20210724-AL-001).

In addition, a heliospheric ensemble model was carried out for the 2021-07-24T00:36Z CME. For 48 ensemble members, simulations indicated that the leading edge of the CME would reach STEREO A between about 2021-07-26T17:46Z and 2021-07-27T05:11Z (average arrival 2021-07-27T00:02Z) for 100% of simulations and NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-07-26T20:04Z and 2021-07-26T21:13Z (average arrival 2021-07-26T20:38Z) for 4% of simulations (see notification 20210725-AL-001).

Based on a heliospheric model carried out for the combined front of two CMEs (first, C-type, CME visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-07-26T16:48Z and an S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-07-27T03:24Z), it was estimated that the leading edge would reach NASA missions near Earth at 2021-07-30T03:10Z (+- 7 hours) (see notifications 20210726-AL-001 and 20210728-AL-003). Additionally, an ensemble model was carried out for the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-07-26T16:48Z. The leading edge is estimated to reach STEREO A between about 2021-07-29T19:05Z and 2021-07-30T03:42Z (average arrival 2021-07-30T00:10Z) for 12% of simulations and at NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-07-29T15:32Z and 2021-07-30T08:38Z (average arrival 2021-07-29T23:17Z) for 68% of simulations (see notification 20210728-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-07-22T06:00Z to 2021-07-22T09:00Z. This slightly elevated value of Kp was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-07-19. 

A significant interplanetary shock was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2021-07-27T16:57Z (see notification 20210728-AL-001). The shock is associated with a coronal hole high speed stream arrival on 2021-07-28.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-07-23T21:36Z     ~514            C               -78/-8                18                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2021-07-24T00:36Z     ~600            C               -46/-3                39                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2021-07-26T16:48Z     ~531            C               -19/-17               36                          SOHO, STEREO A        

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-07-26T02:48Z     ~545            C               -/11                  10                          SOHO
2021-07-26T21:12Z     ~554            C               -/10                  33                          SOHO

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-07-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-08-03T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary from low to minor levels for the outlook period. 5 numbered active regions are currently on the Earth facing disk, 12846, 12847, 12848, and 12849, with 12848 soon rotating off the Earth facing disk. Active regions 12849 and 12846 have been producing B-class flares. Active region 12849 may have been responsible for C-type CMEs at 2021-07-23T21:36Z and 2021-07-24T00:36Z, and the active region 12847 may have been responsible for the C-type CME at 2021-07-26T16:38Z. This activity might continue during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary from below minor to moderate levels during the outlook period due to the predicted arrivals at L1 of the 2021-07-24T00:36Z CME on 2021-07-27, the 2021-07-26T16:48Z CME on 2021-07-29, and the 2021-07-27T03:24Z CME on 2021-07-30. An equatorial coronal hole structure extending west on the Earth facing disk associated with the interplanetary shock at 2021-07-27T16:57Z and the coronal hole high speed stream arrival on 2021-07-28 is expected to remain geoeffective through the early part of the outlook period.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs update (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-28T12:55:51Z
## Message ID: 20210728-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20210728-AL-002).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs have little or no impact on Juno or Dawn.

Previous simulations also estimate that the CME may affect STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach STEREO A at 2021-07-30T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
Previous simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-07-30T03:10Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).

CME parameters are (C-type):

Start time of the event: 2021-07-26T16:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~531 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 36 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -19/-17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235100_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235100_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235100_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235100_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235200_5.5_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235200_5.5_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235200_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Juno_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_235200_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Dawn_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001) is associated with B2.2 flare with ID 2021-07-26T14:57:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-07-26T16:09Z.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-28T12:48:45Z
## Message ID: 20210728-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20210726-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2021-07-29T19:05Z and 2021-07-30T03:42Z (average arrival 2021-07-30T00:10Z) for 12% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-07-29T15:32Z and 2021-07-30T08:38Z (average arrival 2021-07-29T23:17Z) for 68% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 92% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-4 range (below minor to below minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085/Detailed_results_20210726_164800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX085.txt
###

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-28T12:41:25Z
## Message ID: 20210728-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2021-07-27T16:57Z. 

The shock is caused by a high speed stream which arrived on 2021-07-28. 

Activity ID: 2021-07-27T16:57:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-26T19:38:46Z
## Message ID: 20210726-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-07-26T16:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~610 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 35 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -8/-3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2021-07-30T01:30Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-07-29T15:17Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_215800_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_215800_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_215800_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_215800_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_215800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210726_215800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-07-26T16:48:00-CME-001) is associated with B2.2 flare with ID 2021-07-26T14:57:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-07-26T16:09Z.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2021-07-20T16:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20210721-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 40 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2021-07-22T18:06Z and 2021-07-23T02:58Z (average arrival 2021-07-22T21:53Z) for 57% of simulations.

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-22_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083/20210720_194300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-22_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083/20210720_194300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-22_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083/20210720_194300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-07-22_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083/Detailed_results_20210720_194300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX083.txt

The original non-ensemble simulation (notification 20210721-AL-001) also indicated that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. The non-ensemble simulation indicated that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-07-23T17:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor) in the original simulation.
###

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 14, 2021 - July 20, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-21T21:13:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-07-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-07-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210721-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high level during this reporting period, with one R-type CME, one O-type CME and three C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the R-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-07-15T21:36Z may impact OSIRIS-REx at 2021-07-17T04:19Z, Mars at 2021-07-18T18:45Z and might give Solar Orbiter a glancing blow at 2021-07-17T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20210716-AL-001 and 20210718-AL-001). The O-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-07-17T05:24Z was predicted to impact OSIRIS-REx at 2021-07-19T12:15Z, Solar Orbiter at 2021-07-19T04:13Z and Mars at 2021-07-21T12:29Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20210717-AL-001). The C-type CME initially observed in STEREO A COR2 at 2021-07-20T16:48Z was predicted to have a minor impact at STEREO A at 2021-07-22T19:00Z and possibly give a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-07-23T17:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20210721-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-07-14T15:00Z to 2021-07-14T21:00Z. This slightly elevated value of Kp was associated with the arrival of the CME initially observed on 2021-07-10T13:36 detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-07-14(see notification 20210714-AL-001).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-07-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-07-27T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Six numbered Active Regions are currently on the Earth-facing disk, 12842, 12844, 12845, 12846, 12847 and 12848, with 12842 and 12845 soon rotating off the Earth-facing disk. Several more unnumbered Active Regions currently on the STEREO A facing disk are expected to cross onto the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period. One of these Active Regions may have produced the non-Earth-directed R- and O-type CMEs on 2021-07-15 and 2021-07-17, respectively, while located behind the East limb in STEREO A. On 2021-07-20 the Active Region 12846 produced a C-type CME. This activity might continue during the outlook period.

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels for the upcoming week due to the predicted glancing blow at L1 on 2021-07-23 of the CME initially observed by STEREO A on 2021-07-20. A small southern extension of the north polar coronal hole at the center meridian in STEREO A on 2021-07-21 may possibly affect STEREO-A early around 2021-07-24 and may potentially become geoeffective late in the outlook period.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-07-20T16:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~971 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -43/26 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-07-20T16:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A (minor impact).  The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2021-07-22T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-07-23T17:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 07, 2021 - July 13, 2021
##

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period. There were 6 C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME starting at 2021-07-10T17:38Z may impact OSIRIS-REx at 2021-07-13T14:05Z and Mars as a glancing blow at 2021-07-16T08:00Z.  It was also estimated that the CME starting at 2021-07-12T06:36Z may have a glancing blow both at OSIRIS-REx and Mars on 2021-07-15T00:00Z and 2021-07-17T16:00Z, respectively. Finally, the CME that started on 2021-07-13T18:53Z was estimated to have an impact at OSIRIS-REx at 2021-07-16T18:33Z (see notification 20210714-AL-002). All predictions have difference hours of +/- 7 hours.  

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-07-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-07-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. There are currently three numbered Active Regions (12839, 12841, and 12842) visible on the Earth-facing solar disk, with Active Region 12839 expected to rotate off the disk early in the outlook period. These Active Regions may produce B-class and some C-class flares. An unnumbered Active Region which rotated onto the STEREO A facing disk around 2021-07-12 is expected to cross onto the Earth-facing disk around 2021-07-18. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A northern extension of the southern polar coronal hole currently visible towards the SW limb of the Earth-facing disk (as observed in the available SDO EUV imagery on 2021-07-13) may become geoeffective around 2021-07-15.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 30, 2021 - July 06, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-07-07T22:40:20Z

## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-07-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210707-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with one X-class and three M-class flares from Active Region 12838 as it was rotating off the Earth-facing solar disk (see list below), and one non-Earth directed C-type CME (see details below).  There were no significant CMEs associated with these flares. 

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-06-30T18:00Z to 2021-07-01T00:00Z. This slightly elevated value of Kp was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-30. Solar wind speeds from this event reached values around 520 km/s on 2021-06-30 and decreased to around 320 km/s by the end of the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-07-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-07-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active Region 12838 which produced significant flares during this reporting period has rotated far beyond the limb, and Active Regions 12835 and 12836 are expected to rotate off the Earth-facing disk at the beginning of the outlook period. There are currently three numbered Active Regions (12837, 12839 and 12840) visible on the Earth-facing solar disk, with Active Regions 12840 and 12839 expected to rotate off the disk early in the outlook period. These Active Regions may produce B-class and some C-class flares. An unnumbered Active Region which rotated onto the STEREO A facing disk around 2021-07-06 is expected to cross onto the Earth-facing disk around 2021-07-10. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A small equatorial coronal hole structure at central meridian on 2021-07-07 might become geoeffective around 2021-07-11, and a large northern extension of the southern polar coronal hole nearing the central meridian in SDO is expected to become geoeffective at the end of the outlook period. 


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
